conclusion: Understanding the principles of total internal reflection and geometry involved.
A laser beam is injected into the optical fiber at point O with an incident angle α = 45°.
Total internal reflection occurs at the side of the optical fiber.
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence inside the fiber is greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle θc is given by sin θc = n2/n1.
The laser beam enters at O and hits the side of the fiber at point A.
The angle of incidence at A is θ.
The angle θ is related to the incident angle α and the angle of refraction β at the entry point O.
Using Snell's Law at point O: n1 sin α = n2 sin β.
Given α = 45°, we have n1 sin 45° = n2 sin β.
For total internal reflection, θ must be greater than the critical angle θc.
The angle θ is related to β by the geometry of the fiber: θ = 90° - β.
Final expression for θ: θ = 90° - arcsin((n1 √2)/(2 n2)).
